section.title: Downloading and Running the VM using Virtual Box
section.note: Virtual Box is required to run the virtual machine on your computer. If you do not already have it installed, download the binary version desired and install it from the Virtual Box Website .

section.title: Running the VM with Virtual Box
section.para: Follow these steps to add the vmdk file to Virtual Box and create a virtual machine inside the Virtual Box
1. Launch Virtual Box on your machine.
2. In the Icon Menu, select New
The Create New Virtual Machine Wizard Welcome window opens up.
3. Select Next
4. Enter a name for the virtual machine.
5. Select Linux as the Operating System and Debianas the Version from the pull down menus. Select Next
6. Select the base recommended Base Memory Size then select Next
7. Select Use existing hard disk.
8. Open the file icon and navigate to the location of the Debian-6-86 file downloaded earlier. Once a file has been selected, it is available in the pull down menu.
9. Double click the Debian-6-86 file to launch the Create New Virtual Disk Wizard.
10. Select Next
11. Select the desired storage type then select Next
12. Select the desired location and virtual disk size, then select Next
13. Review the settings and select Finish to create the virtual disk or Cancel to cancel creation
The VM is created and will appear in the VirtualBox Manager window in a powered off state
14. Double click the VM to launch the First Run Wizard
Select Next
The Starting VM progress window opens and tracks the creation process
When completed the virtual home page page is displayed
15. Select Accessories - LX Terminal to open a terminal window.

When the virtual machine starts , it automatically logs you in as user tutorial.
The Terminal Window opens:
Note: The terminal window is the main interface for the walkthrough process.

section.title: Walkthrough Workflow
section.para:
Workflows are at the center of how Pegasus operates. Pegasus takes in an abstract workflow ( DAX ) and generates an executable workflow (DAG) that is run in an environment. For the purposes of this walkthrough, we will demonstrate the characteristics and structure of workflows by generating a workflow with a bit of Java code that uses the DAX API to generate a DAX workflow.
For a detailed description of workflows, how to create them, and how they are used in Pegasus see Creating Workflows

section.title: Planning and Executing Workflows
section.para: In this section you plan and execute a workflow through Pegasus WMS locally. You then plan and execute a larger Montage workflow on the GRID.
1. Open a terminal.
In general, to run workflows on the Grid you will need to obtain Grid Credentials. The VM already has a user certificate installed for the pegasus user.
2. Run the grid-proxy-init command to generate the proxy (grid credentials).
All the exercises in this Chapter will be run from the $HOME/pegasus-wms/ directory . All the files that are required reside in this directory.

section.title: Creating a DIAMOND DAX
section.para: Use these instructions to generate a 4 node diamond dax with a small piece of java code that uses the DAX API to generate the DAX.
1. Open the file $HOME/pegasus-wms/dax/CreateDAX.java in a file editor:
2. Scroll down to the //Add analyze job //To be uncommented for exercise 2.1 code near the end of the file.
The above snippet of code, adds a job with the ID0000004 to the DAX. It illustrates how to specify:

listitem.para: the arguments for the job
the logical files used by the job
the dependencies to other jobs
adding the job to the dax

section.para: 3. Uncomment the code, then compile and run the CreateDAX program as follows:

programlisting.emphasis:
$ cd dax
$ javac -classpath .:/opt/pegasus/default/lib/pegasus.jar CreateDAX.java
$ java -classpath .:/opt/pegasus/default/lib/pegasus.jar CreateDAX local /opt/pegasus/default ./diamond.dax

section.para: 4. View the generated diamond.dax.
The job output is displayed
The DAX contains four sections.

listitem.para: Section 1. Files - Acts as a Replica Catalog
Section 2. Executables - Acts as a Transformation Catalog
Section 3. Transformations - Aggregates, Executables, and Files
Section 4. Jobs DAXs or DAGs - Defines a Job, DAX, or DAG

section.title: Monitoring Tools
section.para: Pegasus comes bundled with tools for monitoring and analyzing workflows

listitem.para: Pegaus Monitord - Tracks the job states as a workflow is executed
Pegasus Status - Displays the status of the workflow individual jobs
Pegaus Analyzer - Command line utility for parsing several workflow directory files to summarize useful information for the user
Pegasus Remove - Comand line tool for aborting a workflow

section.para: See "Monitoring Tools"
